Adult and Child Safe Guarding Strategy/ MSEPO-20240 / 1.1
Page  of
Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) is committed to safeguarding all vulnerable people who access services across the Trust. Safeguarding encompasses everything that enables a child, young person or adult at risk to live a life that is free from abuse and neglect and enables them to achieve their full potential and well-being whilst retaining dignity, independence, and choice.

There will be a whole organisational approach to safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children and adults which will be embedded across all of the divisions and services provided by MSE, and in every aspect of the Trust's work. Safeguarding will be considered in all interactions with patients and their carers with the welfare of patients given paramount consideration of all MSE staff. This should be given priority at all times.

MSE will aim to achieve excellence in safeguarding using a continuous learning framework, robust governance arrangements and staff discharging their statutory responsibilities within professional boundaries. The child and/or adults experience will be enhanced through effective partnership working with other agencies to aid seamless service provision.

In accordance with the Children Act 2004 (Section 11) all individuals who work in health care organisations, both substantive staff and those working in services that are contracted or commissioned, must be trained and competent to recognise when a child may need to be safeguarded and know what to do in response to concerns about their welfare. The Care Act (2014) came into force in April  and provides a robust statutory framework to safeguard adults at risk of harm and children transitioning into adult services.

Working Together to Safeguard Children (2018) sets out statutory guidance on the responsibility of NHS organisations in ensuring that employees and independent contractors have an awareness of how to recognise and respond to safeguarding concerns.

Department of Health figures suggest that about 1.5 million people (around 2.5 per cent of the UK population) in the UK have a learning disability. Children, young people and adults with a learning disability and/or autism have the right to the same opportunities as anyone else to live satisfying and valued lives, and to be treated with dignity and respect. They should have a home within their community, be able to develop and maintain relationships, and get the support they need to live healthy, safe and rewarding lives.

The NHS requires health care providers to employ staff with the skill mix appropriate to deliver a high quality service to patients in every circumstance (DH 2010d). This Training and Development Framework seeks to support the delivery of safe, high quality care for people with learning disabilities or autism when they come into hospital and to
ensure that they receive care and treatment that recognises and is responsive to their individual needs.

The launch of the NHS Long Term Plan (2019) has provided additional focus on action the NHS will take to strengthen its contribution to prevention and health inequalities, including mechanisms to ensure that people with a learning disability and/or autism get better support. It sets out actions to improve understanding of the needs of people with a learning disability and/or autism, to improve their health and wellbeing and to tackle the causes of morbidity and preventable deaths.

More recently, the Learning Disabilities Mortality Review (LeDeR) Programme has highlighted the persistence of preventable health inequalities and that people with a learning disability die, on average, 15-20 years sooner than people without a learning disability. The LeDeR programme has highlighted the need for:
Healthcare coordination for people with complex or multiple health conditions
Assurance that effective reasonable adjustments are being provided for people with a learning disability and their families
Mandatory learning disability awareness training for all staff supporting people with a learning disability

The strategy aims to provide information on mandatory safeguarding training requirements for all managers and staff within MSE Trust. This strategy provides guidance on training and competence required by each staff group as per the Intercollegiate Document guidance: Safeguarding Children and Young People: roles and competences for health care staff (2019); Looked after Children: Knowledge, skills and competences of health care staff, Intercollegiate Role Framework (2015) and Adult Safeguarding: Roles and Competencies for Health Care Staff (2018). Core Capabilities Framework for Supporting People with a Learning Disability, Core Capabilities Framework for Supporting Autistic People (2019).

The Prevent Duty  requires all specified authorities including NHS Trusts and Foundation Trusts to ensure that there are mechanisms in place for understanding the risk of radicalisation. Furthermore, they must ensure that health staff understands the risk of radicalisation and how to seek appropriate advice and support.
Purpose

The purpose of this strategy is to provide a framework which ensures MSE Foundation Trust meets its contractual, legislative and statutory responsibilities to equip all staff to work effectively to safeguard and promote the welfare of adults, children and young people.

This policy sets out the key principles that all staff and workers working across the MSE, must comply with when safeguarding children, young people and adults at risk of harm or abuse, and promoting and supporting the rights of individuals with learning disabilities and Autism.

The identification of the level of training required is dependent on the staff member's role and responsibilities as set out in intercollegiate guidance: Safeguarding Children Roles and Competences for Healthcare Staff - Intercollegiate Document, (2019), Adult Safeguarding: Roles and Competencies for Health Care Staff First edition (August 2018) and through the organisations training needs analysis.

All training provided should place the child or adult at risk of abuse as the centre focus, respect diversity (including culture, race, religion and disability), promote equality and encourage the participation of children, families and adults in the safeguarding process and patient pathways.

Learning  opportunities  provided  to  staff  should  embrace  a  wide  range  of  learning methodology and due consideration afforded to knowledge and skill acquisition gained via activities such as clinical supervision, participating in learning reviews including Child Safeguarding Practice Reviews, Safeguarding Adult Reviews (SAR), Domestic Homicide Reviews (DHR), Multi-agency Case Audit, , serious incident reporting and peer review exercises, Internal mortality reviews and  LeDeR  mortality reviews and recommendations.

This  strategy  applies  to  all  employees  and  workers  of  the  MSE  Trust,  including seconders into and out of the organisation, volunteers, students, honorary appointees, trainees,  contractors,  and  temporary  workers,  including  locum  doctors  and  those working on a bank or agency contract.
For ease of reference, all employees and workers who fall under these groups will be uniformly referred to as “staff” in this document
Definitions

table_items.text: An individual who is 18 years of age or over.
In the context of this document to aid inclusion and brevity the composite definition has been used – ‘an adult at risk is any person who is aged 18 years or over and at risk of abuse, harm
or neglect because of their needs for care and/or support and are unable to safeguard themselves

In the context of this document adult safeguarding means to work with an individual to protect their right to live in safety, free from abuse, harm and neglect. This can include both proactive and reactive interventions to support health and wellbeing with the engagement of the individual and their wider community. The aim is to enable the individual to live free from fear and harm and have their rights and choices respected.
A person under the age of 18.

Children defined under Section 17 of The Children Act (1989) as those whose vulnerability is such that they are unlikely to reach or maintain a satisfactory level of health or development, or their health or development would be significantly impaired without the provision of services. Disabled children are also included in this category (The Children's Act (1989) S17d).

This is the statutory activity under Section 47 of the Children Act (1989) that is undertaken to protect specific children who are suffering, or likely to suffer, significant harm as a result of maltreatment or neglect.

Children who are placed in care to the Local Authority and live with Foster Carers, in residential homes or with family members are known as a Looked After Child, a Child Looked After or a child in care.
A multi-agency forum for developing, monitoring and reviewing local child protection arrangements, policies and procedures and where necessary conducting child safeguarding practice reviews.
Under the Children Act 1989, "parental responsibility" means all the rights, duties, powers, responsibilities and authority
which, by law, a parent of a child has in relation to the child and his property.

Safeguarding Adults Boards: Each Local Authority area must have a statutory Safeguarding Adult Board. Their purpose is to help and protect adults at risk through coordination of a multi- agency system made up of Local Authority, NHS commissioners and providers, the Police, and regulatory services.

Safeguarding Adult Review. Safeguarding Adults Reviews (SARs) are a statutory requirement for Safeguarding Adults Boards (SABs). Safeguarding adult practice can be improved by identifying what is helping and what is hindering safeguarding work, in order to tackle barriers to good practice and protect adults from harm.

When a child dies or is seriously harmed* in circumstances where abuse or neglect are known or suspected (i.e. is a serious child safeguarding case), Local Safeguarding Children Partnerships/Boards are required to consider if a Child Safeguarding Practice Review (CSPR) is appropriate to consider the involvement of organisations and professionals with the child and family. *Serious harm is defined as serious or long-term impairment of a child's mental health or intellectual, emotional social or behavioural development, as well as impairment of physical health.
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust: Comprising of Basildon, Broomfield (Mid Essex) and Southend hospitals

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Safeguarding Committees duties are as follows:
Monitoring training compliance amongst other Safeguarding KPI's
Enduring robust systems, processes and procedures are in place
Assurance and Accountability for safeguarding activity
Offer strategic challenge and escalation to divisions and other Committees.

Chief Executive as Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. They ultimately responsibility for ensuring that safeguarding  training  is  provided  in  accordance  with  statutory  organisational responsibilities  outlined  in  Section   of  the  Children's  Act  (2004)  and  Adult Intercollegiate Document (2018). Day to day management of this task is delegated to the Executive Lead for Safeguarding.
Chief Nurse/Director of Nursing/Medical Director – The Executive lead is responsible for supporting the Safeguarding Teams to ensure that resources are provided for all appropriate training.
4.3.1  The Director of Nursing and the Medical Directors on each site will be corporately responsible for the implementation of this strategy. This includes:

When the strategy is reviewed and updated incorporating the time frame for the process to be undertaken. The training strategy will be reviewed every 3 years unless the need for an earlier review is indicated.
Reporting into the necessary governance committees;
Ensuring that MSE provides/supports the training for staff to discharge their responsibilities and that there is an appropriate competency framework to support this.
Heads of Nursing/Head of Midwifery/Matrons/Heads of Departments/Service

Managers/Department Managers – are responsible for the implementation of this strategy at departmental level. This includes: identifying training needs and ensuring staff attend training; assessing service requirements against what the service is delivering.

Designated, Named Professionals and the Safeguarding Team – are experts in safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children and vulnerable adults, therefore champion safeguarding within and external to the MSE.
MSE Safeguarding Team:

4.6.1  Undertake a Training Needs Analysis (TNA) to identify role based training needs as per the Intercollegiate Guidance Safeguarding Children and Young People: Roles & Competencies for Health Care Staff, (2019); Adult Safeguarding: Roles and Competencies for Health Care Staff (2018) and divisional needs, Core Capabilities Framework for Supporting People with a Learning disability ( 2019) and for Supporting Autistic People (2019).
Develop and deliver face to face and eLearning training packages

Cascade learning outcomes and recommendations from SAR's, Child Safeguarding Practice Reviews /Domestic Homicide Reviews, Individual Management Reviews (IMR's) and Serious Incident Investigations (SI).
Keep updated with own mandatory training and addressing any identified training gaps in own practice
Named professionals and safeguarding nurses will provide safeguarding supervision to an identified cohort of staff (on completion of recognised safeguarding supervision course).
Receive and monitor training compliance in accordance with any key performance indicator; escalate non-compliance to the relevant managers/leads.
Other MSE professionals who are able to provide advice and information in relation specifically to safeguarding issues are:
Paediatric Liaison Health Visitor
Paediatric Matron
Paediatricians
Head of Paediatrics
Head of Midwifery
Named Doctor Safeguarding Adults
Learning disability service lead
Adult and Child Service leads and Specialists
Learning disability liaison nurse specialists.

4.7.1  In the absence of one or more of the above professionals, advice can be sought from MSE senior paediatric professionals; on-call paediatric registrar and on-call Paediatrician for Child Protection via switchboard, site coordinators, Matrons and, in addition, advice can be sought by the relevant local authority Children's Social Care department and Adult Social care (Intranet site for polices and on-call managers).
Duties of all MSE staff (substantive or non-substantive, including volunteers)
Attend or complete Corporate Induction on their first day of employment or as indicated in employment contract.

Attend further safeguarding training as identified within the Intercollegiate Guidance Safeguarding Children and Young People: Roles & Competencies for Health Care Staff  and divisional needs assessment and Adult Intercollegiate Document (2018).
To be responsible for identifying individual additional learning needs and to ensure that they remain active on any professional register.

Safeguarding is each individual employee's responsibility as set out in Working Together to Safeguarding Children (2018), the Southend, Essex and Thurrock (SET) Interagency Child Protection and Safeguarding Procedures (2019), The Care Act (2018), and the Southend, Essex and Thurrock (SET) Safeguarding Adults Guidelines ( 2019).

4.8.1  “All those who come into contact with children and families in their everyday work, including people who do not have a specific role in relation to child protection, have a duty to safeguard and promote the welfare of children” (What To Do If You Are Worried A Child Is Being Abused, 2015).

All staff working within the MSE group should understand what safeguarding is and their role in adult safeguarding work, recognise an adult potentially in need of safeguarding and take action, understand dignity and respect when working with individuals, have knowledge of policy, procedures and legislation that support adult safeguarding activity.
Be alert to potential indicators of abuse or neglect in children and adults and be able to respond to abuse.
Work effectively and liaise with professionals within the Trust and other partner agencies;
Be aware of the “Think Family” approach to consider if other children or adults may be at risk
Duties of Clinical Bank and Agency Staff Working for the Trust

4.9.1  The MSE group is committed to professionally developing clinical bank and agency staff to take an active professional role in adult and child protection. This development is facilitated through training and regular supervision:
All staff are expected to work within safe parameters and their professional code of practice as determined by their statutory regulator requirements.
To liaise with the appropriate agencies in the identification of suspected physical abuse, sexual abuse, emotional abuse and neglect and the assessment of children in need;

To liaise with appropriate agencies in relation to suspected physical abuse, domestic violence and abuse; including so called ‘honour' based crimes and forced marriage, sexual abuse, psychological abuse, financial or material Abuse, modern slavery, human trafficking, discriminatory abuse, organisational abuse, neglect and acts of omission and self-neglect
Bank and agency staff must work to the Trust's policies and procedures.

It is the responsibility of the bank/agency practitioner to professionally update on child protection and adult safeguarding issues and where appropriate to attend mandatory and relevant study days. Bank and Locum staff are linked to the MSE ILearn and mapped to the appropriate level of safeguarding training provided internally across the MSE. The employing Agency has a responsibility to ensure that their agency staff have the appropriate safeguarding training compliance, and are expected to provide this assurance the MSE. Agency staff can attend MSE delivered safeguarding training if agreed by the agency.

Managers and Team Leaders will be responsible for monitoring the actions of their staff to safeguard and promote the welfare of children and adults via access to supervision and personal development reviews.
Additionally, all commissioned providers irrespective of CQC registration must comply with the standards applicable to training set out in the CCG Safeguarding Benchmarking Policy, in particular;

Standard 5.4: Staff accesses a comprehensive training programme which is monitored across all levels of the organisation. Awareness training is mandatory for all staff with a tiered approach to meet more complex needs. Staff will be trained to the required level to respond and act upon their concerns in line with their role and responsibilities, using nationally validated training competencies where available, and;
Standard 7.7: Staff has access to a range of training opportunities arising from lessons learnt.
Training Strategy
Training Needs Analysis

5.1.1 The MSE Corporate Safeguarding Team has completed a training needs analysis in response to the Core Capabilities Framework for Supporting People with a Learning Disability and the new Core Capabilities Framework for Supporting Autistic People., Safeguarding Children and Young People: Roles and Competencies for Health Care Staff (2019); Adult Safeguarding: Roles and Competencies for Health Care Staff (2018) which is endorsed by the Department of Health, The British Association of Social Workers, Royal College of Physicians, Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, Royal College of Nursing and Royal College of Midwives, see Appendix 2

5.1.2 These documents provide a competency framework and sets out the levels of competence with the timescales required by different groups of healthcare and the type of training requirements necessary in order to ensure appropriate statutory training provision see Appendix 3

5.1.3 Furthermore, divisional training needs analysis was completed on recognition that the divisions tend to have a mixed cohort of patients. Although the intercollegiate expectation is that divisions with a mixed cohort should be trained at a minimal of level 2, a small cohort of professionals in adult divisions who had paediatric interest were mapped at level 3 to ensure they offer the division that level of skill and competence required in complex cases.

Safeguarding Training Principles

5.2.1 The MSE training programme aims to ensure that MSE staff work effectively and collaboratively within the organisation and with external agencies to safeguard and promote the welfare of adults and children.
5.2.2 This will be achieved by:
The development and shared understanding of the tasks, processes, principles, roles and responsibilities outlined in national guidance. This includes local arrangements for safeguarding.
Improved communications between professionals including a common understanding of the key terms, definitions and thresholds for action.
Effective working relationships, including an ability to work in multidisciplinary groups or teams.
Effective, child and adult at risk focused decision making based on information sharing, assessment, critical analysis and sound professional judgement.
Learning from Child Safeguarding Practice Review, DHR, SAR and reviews from child deaths.
Offering training that is child-centred ensuring the children's rights and needs are made paramount without negating a Think Family approach.
Underpinning training with research, evidence and national guidance
All level 3 training should have a multiagency approach.
Ensuring that ultimately safeguarding training serves to improve the quality of practice and positively affect outcomes for children, young people and adults at risk.
Training packages are reviewed 6 monthly to ensure they reflect current guidance and are fit for purpose. Training is evaluated via a regular knowledge and skills audit and practitioner evaluation.
Training Levels and Delivery Mode
Safeguarding Children Training

6.1.1 Level : This level is equivalent to the core safeguarding/ child protection training across all organisations working with children and young people and is for all healthcare staff regardless of place of work.
6.1.2 Training Requirement & Delivery
Training at a minimum ofhours over a period of 3 years.
E-Learning Package for level 1 and 2 Training (eLFh)

6.1.3 Level : This level is for Non-clinical and clinical staff that in their role have contact (however small) with children, young people and/or parents/carers or adults who may pose a risk to children.
6.1.4 Training Requirement & Delivery
Training at a minimum ofhours over a period of 3 years.
E-Learning Package for level 2 Training (eLFh)
Level 2 training will include the update and requirement for level 1 therefore negating the need to undertake a refresher for level 1.

6.1.5 Level : This training is for all clinical staff that work with children, young people and their families or adults who could potentially cause risk to children, and have potential to contribute to the assessing, planning, intervening or evaluating the needs of a child, young person and/or an adults parenting capacity.

6.1.6 Level : Additional knowledge, skills and competencies: This training is for specific roles within the trust that require added competences and identified as follows paediatricians, forensic physicians, children's nurses, midwives, paediatric surgeons, urgent and unscheduled care, obstetricians, neonatologists, paediatric intensivists and lead anaesthetists for Child protection.
6.1.7 Training Requirement & Delivery
*Training requirements at Level 3 are mapped to individual staff I-learn profiles.
Initial Level 3 training:
Professionals will complete the equivalent of a minimum of 8 hours education, training and learning related to safeguarding/child protection.
Those requiring role specific additional knowledge, skill and competencies* should complete a minimum of 16 hours.

It is expected that those individuals who have not yet attained the knowledge, skills and The competence for level 3 should acquire these within a pre-defined timeframe as agreed with their mentor/appraiser. The timeframe for this initial training should not exceed a 3 month period.
Refresher level 3 training:
Over a three-year period, professionals should be able to demonstrate refresher education, training and learning equivalent to:
a minimum of eight hours for those requiring Level 3 core knowledge, skills and
competencies
a minimum of 12-16 hours for those requiring role specific additional knowledge, skills and competencies*.

Safeguarding Children Training at level 3 ( initial and refresher) could be a combination of e-learning (eLFh); attendance at face to face half day training with pre- read material and resources, personal reflection and discussion in clinical meetings, Peer Review, safeguarding updates, workshops, or attendance at internal or external safeguarding study days at level
Level 3 training will include the update and requirement for level 1 and 2 therefore negating the need to undertake a refresher for level 1 and 2
Level 4: This training is for specialist safeguarding children and young people professionals such as safeguarding advisors and Named Professionals.
Training Requirement & Delivery

All safeguarding professionals requiring training at level 4 & 5 should be familiar with the detailed requirements set out in the Intercollegiate Document - Safeguarding Children and Young People: Roles and Competencies for Healthcare Staff Fourth edition: January 2019. Requirements include:
That Safeguarding professionals should attend a minimum ofhours of education, training and learning over a 3 year period.
Level 4 training updates staff on level 1-3 training negating the need for refresher training at these levels
Competency can be achieved via Safeguarding Conferences and Externally commissioned training.
Named Professionals responsible for training of doctors are expected to have appropriate education for this role.
6.1.8 Level : This training is for specialist safeguarding children and young people professionals working as designated professionals
6.1.9 Training Requirement & Delivery
Safeguarding professionals should attend a minimum ofhours of education, training and learning over a 3 year period
Level 5 training updates staff on level 1-4 training negating the need for refresher training at these levels
Competency can be achieved via Safeguarding Conferences and Externally commissioned training
6.1.10 Board Level: This training is for the chief executives, trust executive and non- executive board members
6.1.11 Training Requirement & Delivery

Board members will require a tailored package equivalent to a minimum ofhours to be delivered which encompasses level 1knowledge, skills and competences, as well as Board level specific areas as identified in the intercollegiate guidance for both adults and for Children (2018, 2019).
Competency can additionally be achieved via Safeguarding Conferences and Externally commissioned training
Over a three-year period, board members should receive refresher training equivalent to a minimum of two hours.
Safeguarding Adult Training

Adult Training levels of competency have been identified in line with Intercollegiate Guidance: Adult Safeguarding: Roles and Competencies for Health Care Staff First edition (August 2018) and give examples of staff groups that fall within each of the levels
6.2.1 Level 1: All staff working in health care settings.
6.2.2 Training Requirement & Delivery
Training at a minimum ofhours over a period of 3 years.
E-Learning Package for level 1 and 2 Training
6.2.3 Level 2: Practitioners who have regular contact with patients; patient's families; or with patient's carer's.
6.2.4 Training Requirement & Delivery
Training at a minimum of 4 hours over a period of 3 years.
E-Learning Package for level 2 Training
Level 2 training will include the update and requirement for level 1 therefore negating the need to undertake a refresher for level 1.

6.2.5 Level : Registered health care staff working with adults who engaging in assessing, planning, intervening and evaluating the needs of adults where there are safeguarding concerns (as appropriate to role).
6.2.6 Training Requirement & Delivery

Training, learning and education at a minimum of 8 hours in the initial stage would be inclusive of any pre-reading materials given prior to the taught aspect of any classroom face to face half day training session.
Additional training, education and learning opportunities should be
multidisciplinary and inter-agency where possible.

Training and learning should encourage personal reflection and may include scenario-based discussion, drawing on case studies, Serious Adult Reviews, Domestic Homicide Reviews, lessons from research and audit. This should be appropriate to the specialty and roles of the participants
Level  training will include the update and requirement for level  and 2 therefore negating the need to undertake a refresher for level 1 and 2
Over a three-year period, professionals at level 3 should receive refresher training equivalent to a minimum of eight hours.

As per Intercollegiate guidance (2019), for those individuals moving into Level 3 adult safeguarding posts who have as yet not attained the relevant knowledge, skills and competence required at level 3 it is expected that within twelve months of appointment additional tailored education will be completed equivalent to a minimum of eight hours of education and learning related to adult safeguarding and have an appropriate supervision in place.
6.2.7 Level 4: For specialist roles – Named Professionals.
6.2.8 Training Requirement & Delivery
Safeguarding professionals should attend a minimum of   hours of education, training and learning over a 3 year period.
Level  training updates staff on level 1-3 training negating the need for refresher training at these levels
Competency can be achieved via Safeguarding Conferences and Externally commissioned training
6.2.9 Level : For specialist roles – Designated Professionals.
6.2.10 Training Requirement & Delivery
Safeguarding professionals should attend a minimum of   hours of education, training and learning over a 3 year period
Level  training updates staff on level 1-4 training negating the need for refresher training at these levels
Competency can be achieved via Safeguarding Conferences and Externally commissioned training

6.2.11 Board level: Chief executive officers, trust and health board executive and non- executive directors/members, commissioning body directors. This includes boards of private, independent and charitable health care and voluntary sector as well as statutory providers.
6.2.12 Training Requirement & Delivery

Board members will require a tailored package equivalent to a minimum of 2 hours which encompasses level 1knowledge, skills and competences, as well as Board level specific areas as identified in the intercollegiate guidance (2018, 2019).Competency can additionally be achieved via Safeguarding Conferences and externally commissioned training and learning events.
Over a three-year period, board members should receive refresher training equivalent to a minimum of two hours.

Staff groups are identified at each level, these are not exhaustive lists. It is recognised that there are a plethora of roles which are likely to increase over the coming years. The staff groups identified are examples of the types of role which correspond to the stated level. For further detailed information practitioners may approach their individual colleges/professional bodies.

Domestic abuse is included as part of the Trust Safeguarding Children and Safeguarding Adults Training which all staff are required to attend. Additional training can be provided to specific areas, as requested.

6.2.13 Prevent- Prevent is part of the Government counter-terrorism strategy CONTEST2 and aims to reduce the threat to the UK from terrorism by stopping people becoming terrorists or supporting terrorism.

6.2.14 The Prevent Duty 2015 requires all specified authorities including NHS Trusts and Foundation Trusts to ensure that there are mechanisms in place for understanding and recognising the risk of radicalisation, how to report concerns and what support processes are in place for individuals.
6.2.15 All healthcare / Trust staff may meet and treat people who could be vulnerable to being drawn into terrorism.

The Trust must ensure that Trust staffs understand who may be at greater risk of radicalisation and are able to identify early signs individuals may exhibit that could give rise for concern. Staff need to be able to know how to appropriately refer concerns to seek advice, support from safeguarding leads and the Prevent operational lead to allow for concerns to be assessed against Prevent procedures and further supportive referrals according to established Prevent procedures if necessary.

Prevent referral and training compliance reports are completed and submitted quarterly to local safeguarding leads. Local reporting is also completed and submitted in order that a joint MES report is submitted to Commissioners and NHSE/I regional Prevent Partners
Prevent Awareness Training
6.2.16 Basic level 1 & 2 Prevent awareness training.
6.2.17 All staff will be required to complete basic PREVENT awareness training. This training need applies to all staff requiring level 1 & 2 safeguarding training.
6.2.18 This will be delivered through corporate inductions training and E-learning and needs to be repeated on a   year cycle in accordance with the PREVENT and Trust's Training Needs Analysis.
6.2.19 Enhanced Prevent awareness training (Workshop Raising Awareness of Prevent (WRAP)

6.2.20 Staff requiring to complete level 3,  and  safeguarding training are required to complete the enhance Prevent training. This training will be delivered by face to face training referred to as HealthWRAP or by individuals completing the accredited level 3 E-Learning Prevent course available on the Trust E-Learning system.
6.2.21 This training will need to be repeated every 3 years in accordance with the PREVENT and Trust's Training Needs Analysis.
6.2.22 Competency Level for organisational Prevent Leads

6.2.23 Level 4 training is required for named professionals and level 5 prevent training is required for designated professional such as the Trusts operational Prevent lead. This training is provided by regional Prevent agencies.
6.2.24 Below is a summary of Level 4 & 5 competencies for Prevent leads.

data.text: Learning Disability Training
6.3.1 Tier 1-Those that require general awareness of people with a learning disability and the support they need.

6.3.2 Relevant to those in working in any sector who may occasionally interact with those affected by a learning disability but who do not have responsibility for making decisions about their care or support. For example, this may include those working in education, policing, custodial care, housing or indeed any organisation. This is also relevant to the entire health and social care workforce including ancillary and clerical staff.

6.3.3 Tier   is  also  relevant  to  the  family,  friends  and  carers  of people  with  a learning disability, to ensure they are making the most of the support on offer and can plan effectively for current and future needs.
6.3.4 Capability  1:  Learning  Disability  Awareness  brings  together  the  Tier   learning outcomes. For example, this would be relevant to an introductory learning disability awareness course.
6.3.5 Tiers 2 and 3 provide coverage of capabilities in greater breadth and depth.
6.3.6 Training Requirement & Delivery
Training at a minimum of 2 hours over a period of 3 years.
Corporate Trust Induction face to face level 1 training
E-Learning Package for level 1 and 2 Training

6.3.7 Tier -Health and social care staff and others with responsibility for providing care and support for a person or people with a learning disability, but who would seek support from others for complex management or complex decision-making.

6.3.8 This is relevant to health and social care workers providing care and support, including care assistants working in residential or home care, personal assistants and others in roles which facilitate access to care.
6.3.9 Tier 2 may also be relevant to family and friends who are providing care and support.
6.3.10 Tier 2 also underpins the more specialist skills and knowledge required at tier
6.3.11 Training Requirement & Delivery
Training at a minimum of 4 hours over a period of 3 years.
E-Learning Package for level 2 Training
Level 2 training will include the update and requirement for level 1 therefor negating the need to undertake a refresher for level 1.

6.3.12 Tier 3 Health- social care and other professionals with a high degree of autonomy, able to provide care in complex situations and/or may also lead services for people with a learning disability.

6.3.13 This is relevant to staff working intensively with people with a learning disability including those who take a lead in decision-making and developing or disseminating good practice. For example, this may include (but is not limited to) learning disability nurses, clinical psychologists, psychiatrists, GPs with special interest in learning disability, allied health professionals, social workers etc. It may also include registered managers and other social care leaders including operational managers who have responsibility for services which provide care and support to people with a learning disability.
6.3.14 Training Requirement & Delivery
Learning Disability professionals should attend a minimum of 24 hours of education, training and learning over a 3 year period
Competency can be achieved via Specialist Conferences and Externally commissioned training
Dementia Training

6.4.1 A national training framework has been designed as a comprehensive resource to support the development and delivery of appropriate and consistent dementia education and training for the health and social care workforce. It sets out the essential skills and knowledge necessary for all staff and carers involved in the dementia care pathway from effective basic training to continuous professional and vocation development in dementia aimed at experts and those leading and influencing dementia services.
6.4.2 Training Requirement & Delivery
Tier : raising dementia awareness, in terms of knowledge, skills and attitudes for all those working in health and social care settings
Tier : knowledge, skills and attitudes for roles that have regular contact with people living with dementia
Tier : enhancing the knowledge, skills and attitudes for experts working with people living with dementia
6.4.3 Tier - Broomfield - Booklet handed out at induction, Southend / Basildon - E- learning
6.4.4 Tier - each site has their own training package face to face training - delivered over 1 day
6.4.5 Tier -is delivered via university (ARU) module
Training Requirements
In order for the training strategy to be effective, there must be a clear and effective framework that includes:
A mandate across all directorates within the Trust
Clear roles and responsibilities for the delivery of safeguarding training
Standardised Policies, procedures and clinical guidelines that support safeguarding
Trust wide training needs analysis

The Trust continues to offer a training programme which recognises the different levels of  competency  for  different  groups  of  staff  (Refer  to  Appendix   for  detailed competencies  and  staff  groups).  The  levels  are  based  on  the  directions  of  the intercollegiate documents for adults and for children, and are combined in the method of delivery – appendix
Core Capabilities Framework for Supporting People with a Learning Disability and the new  Core  Capabilities  Framework  for  Supporting  Autistic  People  underpin  the associated training.
Monitoring and Audit

To ensure that our training is of a high standard, all safeguarding trainers will complete an external Train the Trainer (Safeguarding) course. All MSE safeguarding trainers will be observed at least once every two years by the Named Nurse/Deputy Associate Director for safeguarding (Children) /Associate Director for Safeguarding (Adults) to ensure  that  they  are  effectively  delivering  safeguarding  training  to  enable professionals to be competent in safeguarding children and young people and adults across  the  MSE  Hospital  Group.  This  process  supports  trainers  as  part  of  their continued professional development and gives assurance to the Organisation of the quality of training.

Evaluation and feedback directs the focus of future or additional leaning provision, and this  is  sought  from  delegates  attending  all  safeguarding  face  to  face  training, safeguarding  workshops,  and  internal  conferences.  The  Impact  of  training  on developing  knowledge  and  on  practice  is  additionally  evaluated  and  discussed  in safeguarding  supervision  and  management  1-1  and  appraisal  processes.  Training evaluation is discussed at the Hospital Operational Safeguarding Committee on each site to inform the training process and identify training needs as appropriate.

Equality impact assessment
This Policy has been the subject of an Equality Impact Assessment. The output of the assessment demonstrates that no-one, as a consequence of this Policy, is placed at a disadvantage over others.

The MSE Trust accepts that to accommodate the needs of the increasingly diverse community it serves it must ensure the highest levels of awareness and understanding of equality and diversity amongst its staff.

The MSE Trust aims to deliver healthcare services that are equitable and are appropriate to each service user's need regardless of age, disability, race, ethnic origin, gender, religion, belief, sexual orientation or domestic circumstances.
Access to services can be affected by a lack of familiarity with health services, the ability to speak English, cultural practices, expectations and other factors.
